pages:
STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 23, 2025
DANA KOZIARA
CEDAR CREEK TEACHING FAMILY HOME
1020 SILVER CREEK RD,
MARQUETTE, MI, 49855-8948
Re: License #: CI520283194
SI #: 2025SIC0000564
Dear Ms. Koziara:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Samantha Way at (517) 243-9743.
Sincerely,
Jennifer Pastorick, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
*** This report contains quoted profanity***
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000564
Special Investigation Intake Date: April 16, 2025
License #: CI520283194
Licensee Group Organization: Teaching Family Homes of Upper Michigan
Licensee Designee: James Whalen
Chief Administrator: DANA KOZIARA
Agency Name: CEDAR CREEK TEACHING FAMILY HOME
Agency Address: 1020 SILVER CREEK RD
MARQUETTE, MI 49855-8948
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 11/22/2026
Capacity: 6
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
5/12/2025 Phone Interview
5/12/2025 Phone Interview
5/5/2025 Onsite Inspection Interview
5/2/2025 Phone Interview
4/28/2025 Phone Interview
4/24/2025 Email Other
4/24/2025 Face to Face Interview
4/21/2025 Email Documentation received or sent
4/17/2025 Onsite Inspection Unannounced Visit; Special Investigation
Initiation; Interview
4/16/2025 Email Incident Notification
4/16/2025 Email Other
1

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4134 Religious/spiritual policy and practices.
Section (1) The institution shall have and follow a policy on
Description religious/spiritual participation that contains, at a minimum, both of
the following:
(a) A resident shall not be prohibited from participating in
religious activities and services in accordance with the resident's
own faith and parental direction as long as the participation does
not conflict with the safety and security of the facility.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency staff members inappropriately denied a youth church
attendance.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed on 4/16/2025 and had no further
information.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at Bay Pines Center on
4/24/2025. Youth A reported when she was placed at the facility
youth were able to attend church off grounds on Sundays. Youth
A reported times when youth were unable to attend church due to
the facility not having enough staff to take the youth that wanted to
attend church and staff to remain with youth who did not want to
attend at the facility. Youth A reported she was denied the ability
to attend church once due to “negative interaction”. Youth A
reported a “negative interaction” meant she did not receive the
points the day prior to be able to go off grounds. Youth A reported
Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 were working and Youth A was asked
by Staff 1 if she wanted to attend church that morning and Youth
A stated she did. Youth A reported Staff 2 and Staff 3 told her she
was not able to attend church due to her “negative interaction”
from the day prior and offered her to attend church by watching it
on live TV. Youth A reported she does not feel live TV is the
same as attending church in person and wanted to attend church
in person. Youth A reported this was the only time she was told
she could not go to in person church services. Youth A reported
Youth B was not able to attend church in person as he was just
going for the snacks so he was provided the option of watching
live church service on TV.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/17/2025. Youth B reported youth can attend church off campus
on Sundays at the facility if the youth want to attend service.
Youth B reported Youth A was not able to attend church on
2

2/23/2025 due to her recent panic attacks. Youth B reported this
was the only time that he was aware of where a youth was unable
to attend church services when requested.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/17/2025. Youth C reported youth can attend church on Sundays
off grounds if the youth want to attend as long as the weather is
good. Youth C reported if the weather is bad and roads are icy,
then the facility will live stream the church service on TV. Youth C
reported youth are not able to attend church off grounds if they
have an “interaction” prior to church or if the youth are only
attending the church service to get snacks. Youth C explained
“interaction” as if a youth receives negative points and did not
complete their positive corrections for the points. Youth C reported
she was not aware of any youth being told they were unable to
attend church service.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/17/2025. Youth D reported she chooses not to attend church
while at the facility. Youth D reported Youth A was unable to
attend church on 2/23/2025 due to “something she did” however
Youth D did not know any further information or what Youth A did
that resulted in her not being able to attend church services that
morning.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on 4/17/2025. Chief Administrator reported youth at the
facility can attend church off grounds. Chief Administrator
reported church, recreation activities, and medical appointments
are offered to all youth regardless of if the youth made their points
for the day. If a youth does not make their points, then they are
not able to attend off ground fun activities such as going to the
store to purchase items. Chief Administrator reported Youth A did
not turn in her point card on Saturday night and hid her point card
due to not making her points to be able to go off grounds on
Sunday. Chief Administrator reported Youth A would have still
been able to attend off grounds church service, however Staff 1,
Staff 2, and Staff 3 did not realize this and made the decision
Youth A could not attend off ground church services without
reaching out to Supervisor. Chief Administrator reported Youth A
was offered online live streaming to watch the church service at
the facility.
Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/17/2025. Supervisor reported youth at the facility can attend off
grounds church services on Sundays. Supervisor reported youth
3

can go off ground for church if the facility has a scheduled driver
to take the youth and if the youth does not have negative thirty
points. Supervisor reported if the facility does not have a driver to
take the youth to church or a youth has a negative thirty points
then the facility will stream church live on the TV. Supervisor
reported he did not know if Youth A was denied church on
2/23/2025. Supervisor reported no knowledge of any youth at the
facility being denied church services.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on 4/28/2025. Staff 1
reported she had just returned to work on 2/23/2025 from being off
for a short period of time. Staff 1 reported Youth A asked about
going to church off grounds and Staff 1 learned Youth A had been
in a “negative interaction” the day prior and could not go off
grounds. Staff 1 reported Staff 3 informed Youth A she could not
go off grounds and was offered to attend the church’s online live
service that the church streams. Staff 1 reported no youth has
ever been denied the opportunity to practice their religious beliefs
at the facility, however there are times when youth are unable to
attend off grounds in person services such as due to weather or
staffing however youth are always offered to attend the church’s
online live streaming of the service.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/5/2025.
Staff 2 reported when she arrived at work, she read the shift
notes, and it noted Youth A did not want to go to church that
morning and Youth A had negative inactions the night prior and
needed to do her positive corrections as she had not the night
before. Staff 2 reported Youth A came out of her bedroom and
stated she wanted to go off grounds to church. Staff 2 reported
she had been told by former staff who are no longer employed at
the facility that if a youth was in a negative interaction and had not
completed their positive corrections, the youth were not able to go
off grounds and to offer online church services. Staff 2 reported
Youth A was offered to watch the live stream of church that
morning however became upset due to wanting to go off grounds.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 5/12/2025. Staff 3
reported she and Staff 1 and Staff 2 talked prior to Youth A getting
up about Youth A attending off grounds in person church service.
Staff 3 reported she was concerned to let Youth A go to in person
church service due to Youth A having behavior concerns the night
prior and based on Staff 3’s experience with Youth A she felt
Youth A was “unpredictable” and had concerns on what Youth A
might do. Staff 3 reported when Youth A got up that morning, she
felt by the look on Youth A’s face that it was not safe to take Youth
4

A off grounds to church. Staff 3 reported Youth A was told that
she could not go to church in person however was offered to
watch the live stream church service on TV.
Documents Reviewed:
• Michigan Department of Health and Human Services
Incident Report 208170238 dated 2/23/2025 for Youth A:
Youth A stated she wanted to attend church. Staff were
informed Youth A had earned negative points yesterday
and did not write them down and Youth A’s point card was
missing. Staff 3 told Youth A she could not attend church
off campus because she had no point card from the
previous day to tell if she made privileges or not but instead
offered to put the live stream of the service on the TV for
Youth A to watch.
• Teaching Family Homes Youth and Family Handbook
Religious/Cultural Practices: Staff shall provide youth with
opportunities to attend religious or cultural activities of their
preference. Youth are not required to participate in any
religious event or service. Staff shall provide youth with
transportation to and from religious services or cultural
activities of their preference on a weekly/regular basis
when it is safe to do so. Staff will encourage youth
participation in special cultural/religious events and
coordinate participation of youth in these events.
Supervision of youth for such activities will be incorporated
into individual treatment plans.
• Email dated 12/18/2024 from Program Supervisor to all
Cedar Creek Staff regarding negative interactions:
Interaction Rules: No off campus for 24 hours after-30, the
exception being preplanned group activities.
• Youth A’s Behavior Management Plan/Trauma Safety Plan
dated 1/21/2025 does not document any information
regarding Youth A attending church.
• Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3’s personnel files: Staff 1 had no
discipline and received Cultural Sensitivity training on
5/8/2024. Staff 2 had no discipline and received Cultural
Sensitivity training on 6/28/2023. Staff 3 had no discipline
and received Cultural Sensitivity training on 11/23/2023.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as Youth A was told by staff
she could not attend in person church service however the
facilities internal policy did not clarify when a youth is able to go to
in person service however an email dated 12/18/2024 was sent
5

out to all staff stating youth are able to attend preplanned group
activities when in a negative interaction. Per interview with Chief
Administrator, Chief Administrator reported youth can attend
church, recreational activities, and medical appointments
regardless of their point status.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
• The facility update internal policy to address youth being
able to attend off ground religious services and situations
where youth are unable to attend off grounds church
services to include severe weather conditions and train
staff on the updated policy.
• The facility ensure an approved driver is scheduled every
Sunday to be able to transport youth to church services and
sufficient staffing to ensure coverage is available to be able
to staff for youth wanting to attend church services and
youth wanting to remain at the facility.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
Description (5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity
of the youth's behavior, chronological and developmental age,
size, gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma,
and must be done in a manner consistent with the youth's
treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency staff members did not use their hair release technique as
trained, and they did not deescalate properly.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed on 4/16/2025 and had no further
information.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at Bay Pines Center on
4/24/2025. Youth A reported the morning she was informed she
would not be able to attend in person church due to “negative
interactions” from the previous day, Youth A said she was irritated
and “felt discriminated”. Youth A reported Staff 1, Staff 2, and
Staff 3 were telling her to go to her bedroom. Youth A reported
initially she was not following staff’s direction but eventually went
to her bedroom. Youth A reported she went into her bedroom and
began “blasting” her music as a coping skill. Youth A reported
6

staff came to her door to do checks on her and she was blocking
her door. Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 were attempting to open her
bedroom door and eventually got the door open. Youth A
reported she told staff to close her door and leave her “the fuck
alone”. Youth A reported Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 did not leave
her alone and she heard them laughing and she felt like they were
laughing at her. Youth A reported she opened the door and
began swinging and pulling hair. Youth A reported she was
“swinging and pulling hair” on Staff 1 as Staff 1 was the first
person in front of her. Youth A reported she punched Staff 1
multiple times, bit her on the back, and “supposedly choked her”
however stated she did not know how she choked her from
behind. Youth A reported Staff 1 was knocked unconscious.
Youth A reported she did not know/remember if or what Staff 1
was doing while she was hitting and pulling Staff 1’s hair. Youth A
reported Staff 2 and Staff 3 did not try to restrain her “like they
said they did”. Youth A reported Staff 2 and Staff 3 were putting
their arms out and Youth A reported she was swinging towards
them but they could have restrained her if they tried. Youth A
reported Staff 2 and Staff 3 were telling her to “stop” and “you’re
hurting her”. Youth A reported Youth B and Youth D came out of
their bedrooms and tried to talk to her however, Youth A did not
recall what Youth B and Youth D said to her. Youth A reported
after she got her anger out, she got up and walked away from
Staff 1. Youth A reported this was the first time anything like this
occurred at the facility.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/17/2025. Youth B reported he witnessed some of the incident
that occurred on 2/23/2025. Youth B reported Staff 1, Staff 2, and
Staff 3 were working. Youth B reported Youth A “felt
discriminated” and was beating up Staff 1. Youth B reported Staff
1 was “bloody” and he believed Staff 1 had a broken nose. Youth
B reported he has not seen Staff 1 since the incident. Youth B
reported he was down the hallway when the incident was
occurring, and he witnessed Youth A “pounding” Staff 1’s head on
the floor and Youth A pulling Staff 1’s hair. Youth B reported Staff
1 was attempting to get away from Youth A by “slipping out of”
Youth A’s hands but was not able to. Youth B reported Staff 2
and Staff 3 asked Youth A to “stop” but Youth A did not. Youth B
reported Staff 2 and Staff 3 did not attempt to do anything to stop
Youth A from hurting Staff 1. Youth B reported Staff 2 and Staff 3
did not attempt to restrain Youth A. Youth B reported he believed
Staff 2 and Staff 3 were afraid of Youth A and that was why he
thought they did not attempt to intervene. Youth B reported he
and Youth D attempted to get Youth A to let Staff 1 go. Youth B
7

reported he nor Youth D were not asked to try to get Youth A to let
Staff 1 go. Youth B reported Staff 2 and Staff 3 told him and
Youth D to go back to their bedrooms. Youth B reported the only
intervention Staff 2 and Staff 3 did during the incident was they
told Youth A to let Staff 1 go and to stop.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/17/2025. Youth C reported Youth A assaulted Staff 1 resulting in
Staff 1 being hospitalized. Youth C reported she did not see any
of the incident as she stayed in her bedroom while the incident
occurred.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/17/2025. Youth D reported she witnessed an incident at the
facility on 2/23/2025 where Youth A assaulted Staff 1. Youth D
reported Youth A grabbed Staff 1’s hair and “repeatedly punched”
Staff 1 in the face. Youth D reported she was told to stay in her
bedroom during the incident however Youth D reported she did
not stay in her bedroom. Youth D reported Staff 2 and Staff 3
were on shift with Staff 1 and Staff 2 and Staff 3 “are weaker staff”
and could not restrain Youth A due to Youth A’s size. Youth D
reported she believed Staff 2 and Staff 3 were scared to intervene
and get punched by Youth A. Youth D reported Staff 3 attempted
to intervene once but Youth A began punching toward Staff 3 so
Staff 3 backed up. Youth D was unable to describe how Staff 3
attempted to intervene as she reported she did not recall what
Staff 3 did. Youth D reported Staff 2 called law enforcement to
come assist. Youth D reported no one asked her to come help
however she reported she attempted to get Youth A to let go of
Staff 1 by putting her hands in front of Staff 1’s face to block Youth
A from punching Staff 1.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on 4/17/2025. Chief Administrator reported Youth A
placed Staff 1 in a head lock and was pulling Staff 1’s hair. Chief
Administrator reported Staff 1, Staff 2, nor Staff 3 attempted to
utilize the Handle with Care hair pull technique that the facility
trains in order to get Staff 1 away from Youth A. Chief
Administrator reported Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 did not use the
trained verbal de-escalation techniques that are trained at the
facility as Chief Administrator reported Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3
attempted to open Youth A’s door which she felt did not
deescalate the situation. Chief Administrator reported she felt it
would have been more appropriate to have one staff attempt to
talk to Youth A as well as give Youth A sometime to calm down.
Chief Administrator reported although it was not ideal for Youth A
8

to be blaring her music in the house, it did not need the response
of Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 trying to enter Youth A’s bedroom.
Chief Administrator reported she believed the tone in staff’s voices
were also “condescending” which created more escalation. Chief
Administrator reported she believes staff froze in the incident and
that was why the staff did not use the trained Handle with Care
techniques. Chief Administrator reported she felt staff were scared
as Youth A was bigger and stronger than the staff. Chief
Administrator reported Staff 2 and Staff 3 were talked to regarding
the incident and what they could have done differently as well as
are receiving additional training to prevent future incidents. Chief
Administrator reported the facility has also been scheduling staff
based on ensuring appropriate staffing to ensure staff are able to
manage youth if needed.
Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/17/2025. Supervisor reported he was the on-call supervisor on
2/23/2025. Supervisor reported he received a call from Staff 2
that morning stating, “need help” and then the phone hung up.
Supervisor reported he attempted to call the facility back to gather
more information, however no one was answering the telephone.
Supervisor called Staff 3 who answered and stated Youth A was
assaulting Staff 1. Supervisor reported he pulled up the cameras
and told Staff 3 to call 911. Supervisor reported he went into the
facility and arrived about one minute after law enforcement and
emergency medical services. Supervisor reported after the
incident he reviewed the video and felt Staff 2 and Staff 3 could
have been more hands on and should have utilized Handle with
Care techniques that they are trained to use in situations.
Supervisor reported he does not know if the staff were scared
based on Youth A being larger in size than them or why they did
not attempt to intervene in the situations. Supervisor reported he
has met with Staff 2 and Staff 3 regarding what could have been
done differently, and Staff 2 and Staff 3 are receiving additional
training.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on 4/28/2025. Staff 1
reported Youth A was upset about being told she could not attend
church services in person. Staff 1 reported Youth A was told to go
back to her bedroom as it was before waking hours of 8am. Youth
A refused to go back to her bedroom and Staff 1 reported she
began “teaching to” Youth A for not following staff directions. Staff
1 reported Youth A began walking back to her bedroom, however,
made a comment that staff were not going to like what she was
going to do. Staff 1 reported Youth A began playing loud music in
her bedroom and was blocking her door, so staff were not able to
9

complete checks on her. Staff 1 reported she, Staff 2, and Staff 3
went to do a check on Youth A and were attempting to get Youth
A’s bedroom door open. Once the door was open, Staff 1
reported Youth A grabbed her by the hair and began to “beat” her
for eight to ten minutes. Staff 1 reported she did not recall the
entire incident as she “blacked out” while she was being hit and
her hair pulled. Staff 1 reported Staff 2 and Staff 3 attempted to
restrain Youth A, however, they were unsuccessful due to Youth
A’s size. Staff 1 reported Staff 3 attempted to intervene and use
Handle with Care techniques, however Youth A hit Staff 3 as well
in the face which caused Staff 3’s glasses to break and Youth A
gave Staff 3 a concussion. Staff 1 reported Staff 2 “disappeared”
however did not know where Staff 2 went as she was face down
on the floor as Youth A was hitting her head off the floor, wall, and
door frame. Staff 1 reported she could hear Staff 3 calling for
Staff 2 to come help. Staff 1 reported she felt Staff 3 did
everything she could to try to help and intervene during the
incident, however she felt Staff 2 should not have left the area for
the time she did. Staff 1 reported she used Handle with Care
techniques when Youth A was biting her neck and arm and
described using the Handle with Care bite release technique
which Staff 1 reported she was successful in using. Staff 1
reported she attempted to utilize the Handle with Care hair pull
technique however was unsuccessful, so she tried to just feed her
head closer to Youth A’s hand hold on her hair. Staff 1 reported
Youth B and Youth D came out of their bedrooms during the
incident against staff directions as Youth B and Youth D were told
to go back into their bedrooms. Staff 1 reported she could recall
hearing Youth B tell Youth A to stop and that she was hurting Staff
1. Staff 1 reported Youth D got on the floor next to her and was
telling Youth A to stop due to Staff 1 bleeding. Staff 1 reported
she did not know that she was bleeding and when she heard
Youth D say that she began to panic and “blacked out”. Staff 1
reported she was trained to use verbal de-escalation techniques
at the facility, however, was unable to recall when she last went
through the training. Staff 1 reported staff receive an intensive
forty hours of preservice training and then recertifications every six
months as well as online training.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/5/2025.
Staff 2 reported Youth A was upset that she was told she could
not go off grounds to attend church services and refused to go
back to her bedroom as it was still sleeping hours. Staff 2
reported Youth A eventually went back to her bedroom and Staff 1
or Staff 3, unable to recall who, went and spoke with Youth A.
Youth A was cussing, and Staff 1 or Staff 3 began teaching to
10

Youth A’s cussing using the Teaching Family Model. Staff 2
reported Youth A was given time and space to calm down. Staff 2
reported she went to complete a room check on Youth A and
Youth A was holding her bedroom door shut. Staff 2 reported she
attempted to talk to Youth A, however Youth A had her
headphones on as Staff 2 could hear the music. Staff 2 reported
she was able to open Youth A’s door enough to see Youth A’s
arm. Staff 2 reported she decided to give Youth A some time to
come down, however felt increased checks needed to be
completed every five minutes. Staff 2 reported she went back five
minutes later to complete another check on Youth A and Youth A
was still holding her door closed and was attempting to get her
speaker to work. Staff 2 reported Youth A was able to get her
speaker to work and began blasting music at high volume during
quiet hours. Staff 2 reported she and Staff 1 went to Youth A’s
bedroom to ask her to turn down the music and Youth A ignored
their request. Staff 2 reported Youth A was still blocking her door
however she and Staff 1 were able to open the door a little at
which time they viewed Youth A siting on the floor “kind of crying”.
Staff 2 reported she and Staff 1 gave Youth A a little more time to
calm down and then went back again and could not get Youth A’s
bedroom door open. Staff 2 reported she, Staff 1, and Staff 3 all
attempted and got Youth A’s bedroom door open, and Staff 1
placed her foot in the door to keep the door open. Staff 2 reported
Youth A began swearing and lunged at Staff 1 and grabbed Staff
1’s hair and began biting the back of Staff 1’s neck and screamed
in Staff 1’s ear. Staff 2 reported Youth A began punching Staff 1
in the face multiple times. Staff 2 reported she and Staff 3
stepped in and attempted to restrain Youth A by securing her
arms so Youth A could not hit Staff 1, however, Youth A slipped
out of the restraint and began trying to hit her and Staff 3. Staff 2
reported Youth A slipped out of the restraint as she was swinging
her body and is “very strong”. Staff 2 reported she texted
Supervisor “please help, she is beating us up” and Supervisor told
her to call 911. Staff 2 reported she stepped away to call 911.
Staff 2 reported when she came back, Youth A was still beating up
Staff 1 and punching toward Staff 3 as Staff 3 was attempting to
restrain Youth A. Staff 2 reported Youth D came out of her
bedroom and attempted to help Staff 1 as there was blood all over
the floor. Staff 2 reported Youth D attempted to talk to Youth A
and told Youth A she was hurting Staff 1 and asked Youth A to
stop. Staff 2 reported Youth B was also standing in the hallway,
and she asked Youth B and Youth D to go back into their
bedrooms. Staff 2 reported Youth D started to go back to her
bedroom, however Youth B refused. Staff 2 reported she did not
know what to do as she did not know if she should focus her
11

attention on getting Youth B and Youth D back to their bedrooms
or assist with Staff 1. Staff 2 reported it was difficult to recall all
the events in the order that they occurred however at one point
Youth A had Staff 1 on the ground “bashing her face into the floor
and off the wall”. Staff 2 reported there was blood all over Staff
1’s face and on the floor. Staff 1 was on the floor face down and
Youth A was on Staff 1’s back and had Staff 1 in a choke hold.
Staff 2 reported Staff 1’s body went limp, and Staff 1 passed out.
Staff 2 reported she was telling Youth A to get off Staff 1 and that
she was hurting Staff 1. Staff 2 reported Youth A was not
listening. Staff 2 reported approximately three minutes after Youth
D talked to Youth A, Youth A let go of Staff 1 and walked out of
the house and sat on the side porch. Staff 2 reported she
assisted Staff 1 in the staff office and EMS and law enforcement
arrived. Staff 2 reported Youth A cut her right arm with her nails
and showed a scar on her right arm. Staff 2 reported staff at the
facility are trained to do hair pull release techniques on their own
hair but not when it is on another person. Staff 2 reported she did
not attempt the hair pull release and did not think Staff 1
attempted to do it herself. Staff 2 reported she was not able to get
close enough to Staff 1 as every time she attempted to assist Staff
1, Youth A would punch her. Staff 2 reported Youth A had ahold
of Staff 1’s hair with her left and was using her right arm to punch
Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3. Staff 2 reported she and Staff 3
attempted to place Youth A in a standing PRT restraint two or
three times however Youth A would “throw” them off as Youth A
was stronger and bigger than Staff 2 and Staff 3. Staff 2 reported
she attempted verbal de-escalation with Youth A and offered
Youth A a time in her bedroom to calm down when Youth A was
upset in the living room prior to the assault on Staff 1, as well as
offered Youth A to make a phone call to an approved contact as
they were strategies to use with Youth A per her behavior plan.
Staff 2 reported Staff 3 was asking Youth A to let Staff 1 go, and
what staff could do to help her. Staff 2 reported she felt the
situation was “chaotic” and feels there could be more training for
staff on what to do in these situations. Staff 2 reported she was
afraid for Staff 1; however, she was not afraid of Youth A or being
hit as she has been hit by youth previously. Staff 2 reported she
feels strong, however was not strong enough to maintain the
restraint hold on Youth A.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 5/12/2025. Staff 3
reported Youth A was escalated due to not being able to attend
church. Staff 3 reported Youth A was given time to cool down and
was asked to go back to her bedroom as it was still quiet time at
the facility. Staff 3 reported Youth A was not following staff
12

direction. Youth A was given a few minutes to calm down again
before Staff 1 informed Youth A she would receive negative
interaction points. Staff 3 reported Youth A made a “threat”
however did not recall what at which time Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff
3 went into the staff office and discussed they were concerned
with the threat being a possible “suicidal statement”. Staff 3
reported Youth A was given five minutes at which time she went
with Staff 1 and Staff 2 to complete a check on Youth A who had
gone to her bedroom. Staff 3 reported Youth A was holding her
door closed so staff pushed the door open and were able to see
Youth A’s fingers. Staff 3 reported she, Staff 1, and Staff 2
decided to give Youth A more time to cool down and left her in her
room for about five to seven minutes before going back to
complete another check. Staff 3 reported on the second check;
Youth A was still holding the door closed however they were able
to open the door enough to see Youth A. Staff 3 reported when
she, Staff 1, and Staff 2 went to complete the next check, Youth A
was holding the door and upon Staff 1 and Staff 2 pushing on the
door, Youth A opened the door and grabbed ahold of Staff 1’s hair
and began screaming. Staff 3 reported she and Staff 2 attempted
to restrain Youth A with no success. Staff 3 reported she and
Staff 2 attempted to talk to Youth A and deescalate Youth A by
telling Youth A “you can’t do this” and offered Youth A choices.
Staff 3 reported Youth A began hitting Staff 1 in the face as she
and Staff 2 were attempting to restrain Youth A. Staff 3 reported
Youth A had a “strong hold” on Staff 1’s hair. Staff 3 reported she
and Staff 2 were attempting to secure Youth A’s arms to get her to
stop as Youth A was hitting, biting, and kicked Staff 1. Staff 3
reported Staff 2 left the area to call law enforcement and
Supervisor. Staff 3 reported it was just her with Youth A and Staff
1 and it was difficult for her to protect Staff 1 as Youth A was
hitting her when she attempted to hold Youth A’s arms back. Staff
3 reported Youth A hit her in the stomach, face, arms, and hit her
glasses off her face. Staff 3 reported she attempted to restrain
Youth A however was unable to secure her arms as Youth A has
wide shoulders/chest area and she was unable to get her arms
fully around Youth A due to her and Youth A’s size difference.
Staff 3 reported she was able to hold Youth A’s arms enough in a
loose PRT to slow Youth A’s hits on Staff 1. Staff 3 reported she
continued to try to verbally deescalate Youth A however she felt
panicked as Staff 1 was saying she was being choked and was
about to pass out. Staff 3 reported she attempted to get Youth A’s
arm off Staff 1’s neck by pulling Youth A's arms in the PRT hold.
Staff 3 reported there was a lot of blood, and she began panicking
more as she thought Staff 1 was dead. Staff 3 reported Youth D
came out of her bedroom and got close to Youth A and was trying
13

to talk to Youth A. Staff 3 reported she asked Youth D to go back
to her bedroom, however Youth D was not following her direction.
Staff 3 reported law enforcement arrived, and Youth A walked out
the side door of the house. Staff 3 reported she was unable to
restrain Youth A due to the size difference and Youth A’s strength.
Staff 3 reported she attempted the best she could to hold Youth
A’s arms back in the PRT to at least slow Youth A’s punches
down from connecting with Staff 1’s head while she attempted to
protect Staff 1’s head. Staff 3 reported she did not see Staff 1
attempt the Handle with Care hair pull technique however Staff 1
later told her she attempted. Staff 3 reported all techniques used
were Handle with Care techniques.
Documents Reviewed:
• Michigan Department of Health and Human Services
Incident Report 208170238 dated 2/23/2025 for Youth A:
Youth A was refusing to follow staff instructions and was
taught to using the Teaching Family Homes method. Youth
A went to her bedroom and began blaring music. Staff 2
went to perform a bed check and Youth A was blocking her
door. Staff 2 was able to confirm Youth A’s safety. Five
minutes later Staff 2 took Staff 3 with to assist with room
check on Youth A. Youth A was blocking the door and
Staff 2 asked Staff 1 to also assist in opening Youth A’s
door to ask Youth A to turn the music down. Staff 1 and
Staff 2 pushed Youth A’s bedroom door open, and Staff 1
placed her foot in the door to keep the door open. Staff 1
asked Youth A to turn the music down. Youth A began
screaming and lunged at Staff 1. Youth A grabbed a
handful of Staff 1’s hair and began screaming in Staff 1’s
ear. Youth A bit the back of Staff 1’s neck while holding
fistfuls of Staff 1’s hair. Youth A began punching Staff 1
multiple times in the face, back of the head, arms, chest,
and back. Staff 2 and Staff 3 attempted to block Youth A
from hitting Staff 1. Staff 2 and Staff 3 attempted to restrain
Youth A, however the restraint was unsuccessful. Youth A
began assaulting Staff 2 and Staff 3 by punching them.
Youth A grabbed Staff 2’s arms and attempted to bite Staff
2. Staff 2 managed to pull her arm away and Youth A dug
her nails into Staff 2’s arm and pulled away causing two
cuts on Staff 2’s arm. Youth A then grabbed Staff 1’s arm
and began biting her, causing the skin to break. Staff 2
contacted 911 from the staff office. Staff 2 returned to the
14

area and a youth was standing by Youth A holding Staff 1’s
head up from the floor. Staff 2 asked youth to return to
their bedrooms. Two youth walked toward the situation with
one grabbing Youth A’s arm and asking Youth A to stop.
Youth A continued punching Staff 1. Staff 3 attempted to
block Youth A’s punches and attempted to restrain Youth A
without success. Youth A continued punching Staff 1 and
Staff 3. Youth A punched Staff 3 in the eye causing her
glasses to break. Youth A picked up Staff 1’s head by her
hair and smashed Staff 1’s face into the door. Staff 1
dropped to the floor followed by Youth A. Youth A began
smashing Staff 1’s face onto the floor causing Staff 1’s
nose and mouth to start gushing out blood. Youth A put
Staff 1 in a choke hold and began to choke out Staff 1.
Staff 1 became unresponsive, and her arm flopped to the
floor. Staff 2 and Staff 3 attempted a restraint on Youth A.
Youth A then let go of the choke hold and began to punch
Staff 2 and Staff 3. Youth A got her arm free from the
attempted restraint and began hammer fisting the back of
Staff 1’s head. Staff 1 was unresponsive at this time. A
youth came out and approached Youth A and talked to
Youth A asking Youth A to let go. Youth A sat there on top
of Staff 1 who was unresponsive for a few minutes and
then got up and walked out of the house. Law enforcement
and emergency medical services arrived.
• Teaching Family Homes Physical Restraint Policy: All staff
within our agency who work directly with youth will be trained
in approved crisis prevention and intervention techniques,
this includes but is not limited to: Prevention, de-escalation
techniques, and non-violent responses to assaultive
behaviors, conflict management, minimizing trauma for
youth, and staff emotional self-regulation techniques.
Training will be conducted by certified trainers. Staff are
trained in these techniques prior to being scheduled on shifts
with the youth. Staff must complete refresher training on an
annual (at minimum) basis. Our agency will maintain training
logs and other training documentation to verify staff are
trained.
Emergency Restraints are the use of restraint as a lifesaving
response for a youth. Our agency deems these restraints
allowable in the following situations: an emergency response
to protect the youth or others from unanticipated or severely
aggressive behavior that places the youth or others in serious
15

threat or violence or injury if no immediate intervention occurs.
• Handle with Care Manual for bite release provides instruction
to drive in to the mouth as the staff hooks both nostrils and
applies slow and steady pressure.
• Handle with Care Manual for hair pulls provides instruction for
the individual whose hair is being pulled to take a grip at the
wrist line, pull it in tight to the head, shallow step back, look at
the youth’s knee, nod, when the youth’s hand opens up back
your head out, and slide your thumps up for control.
• Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3’s personnel files: Staff 1 had no
discipline and received Handle with Care training
7/24/2024, Crisis Teaching training 11/16/2023, Corrective
Teaching training 11/17/2023, and Effective Praise training
11/16/2023. Staff 2 had no discipline and received Handle
with Care training 8/12/2024, Staff 3 had no discipline and
received Handle with Care training 7/24/2024, Corrective
Teaching training 11/17/2023, Crisis Teaching training
11/17/2023, and Effective Praise training 6/21/2023.
Video Reviewed:
Video footage of outside Youth A’s bedroom on 2/23/2025
was reviewed on 4/17/2025. Staff 2 was viewed attempting to
push on Youth A’s bedroom door with Staff 1 and Staff 3 behind
her. Staff 1 stepped in and helped Staff 2 push on Youth A’s door
at which time they got the door slightly opened and then let the
door close and stepped back from the door. Staff 1, Staff 2, and
Staff 3 could be viewed smiling and heard laughing on the video
footage. Staff 1 and Staff 2 went back with Staff 3 standing behind
Staff 1 to open the door again as Staff 3 positioned her leg to
support Staff 1 as Staff 1 and Staff 2 pushed the door open. Staff
2 could be viewed still smiling as well as Staff 3 at one another as
they attempted to open Youth A’s bedroom door. Staff 1 and Staff
2 continued to push on Youth A’s bedroom door and were
laughing. Staff 2 told Youth A to turn the music down. Staff 1 told
Youth A she needed to turn the music down as it was very
inconsiderate to the other youth in the house. Staff 1 stated she
understood Youth A was upset with staff, but it did not need to
impact the other youth in the house and if she could please turn
the music down then staff will leave her alone. Staff 1 and Staff 2
continued to push on Youth A’s bedroom door and Youth A came
out of the bedroom and began punching Staff 1. Staff 2 was on
Youth A’s right side and went in to attempt to hook Youth A’s right
arm. Staff 3 was behind Youth A on Youth A’s left side and had
her hands up. Youth A grabbed Staff 1’s hair and pulled Staff 1 in
close to her as Staff 3 was attempting to get Youth A’s left arm.
Staff 2 attempted to create space between Youth A and Staff 1
16

using her forearm against Staff 1 to push Staff 1 away from Youth
A while attempting to get a hold of Youth A’s hand that was pulling
Youth A’s hair. Staff 2 and Staff 3 were able to get in and hook
Youth A’s arms into the standing PRT position while Youth A still
had a hold of Staff 1’s hair. Staff 1 was bent over in front of Youth
A and Youth A was leaning over Staff 1. Youth A kicked her leg at
Staff 2. Staff 2 and Staff 3 maintained Youth A in the hooked
position as Youth A bent down still moving and holding on to Staff
1’s hair. Staff 2 released her right arm and took her cell phone out
of her pocket. Staff 2 used her right arm and placed it on Youth
A’s head. Staff 2 and Staff 3 stood holding Youth A’s arms while
Youth A remained bent over top of Staff 1. Staff 1 was in a
squatted down position on the floor. Staff 2 and Staff 3 directed
Youth A to stop and let go of Staff 1. Youth A was not moving.
Youth A then began screaming and moved and began hitting Staff
1. Staff 3 no longer had a hold of Youth A, Staff 1 went into a
kneeling ball position on the floor and Youth A was on top of her.
Staff 2 and Staff 3 attempted to resecure hold on Youth A and
Youth A began hitting toward Staff 2 and Staff 3. Staff 2 and Staff
3 moved back from Youth A. Youth A stood up and had Staff 1’s
hair in her hand as Staff 1 was in a sitting position on the floor.
Staff 2 told Youth A to “let her go” and Youth A began punching
Staff 1 in the head. Staff 2 moved in closer to Youth A and
appeared to be attempting to get Youth A’s arm. Youth A
continued hitting Staff 1 in the head. Youth A began to try to hit
Staff 2 and Staff 2 stepped back. Youth A continued to hit Staff 1
who was on the floor on her back with her hands on her head.
Youth A had ahold of Staff 1’s hair with her left hand and was
hitting Staff 1 in the head with her right hand. As Staff 2 stepped
closer, Youth A would swing her arm to hit Staff 2. Youth A stood
up and stopped hitting Staff 1 for a second and Staff 2 stated “I
am calling the cops” and walked down the hall into the living room.
Youth A continued to hit Staff 1 in the head. Staff 1 had her arms
up over her head. Staff 3 stepped in toward Youth A and Youth A
moved down the hall and was no longer in the camera view. Staff
3 stepped back and took her glasses off as it appeared Youth A’s
hand hit Staff 3 in the face. Staff 3 was telling Youth A to “leave
her alone” and “stop” as Staff 3 would move in toward Youth A
and Youth A’s arm could be seen hitting toward Staff 3. Staff 3
yelled for Staff 2 to help. Staff 2 was gone from the area for
almost four minutes. Youth, unable to tell who, could be seen
standing in their doorway. Staff 3 told the youth to go back into
their bedrooms. Staff 3 could be heard telling Youth A “I know that
you are angry, I know that you are mad, but hurting people is not
the solution”. Youth A hit Staff 3 throughout this process as Staff 3
was trying to get closer to Youth A. Staff 3 called for Staff 2 again
17

during this time. Staff 3 continuously asked Youth A to “stop” and
“leave her alone”. Youth D walked down the hall and approached
Youth A, however, can not been seen once she was next to Youth
A on the video. Youth D can be heard talking to Youth A however
unclear what she was saying. Youth D walked away and Youth B
walked down the hall and told Youth A to stop. Youth A’s arms
could still be seen swinging and Staff 3 was attempting to move in
toward Youth A. Staff 2 stood behind Youth B and Staff 3. Staff 3
told Youth B to back up. Youth B told Youth A to stop. Youth D
walked back down the hall and Staff 2 told Youth D to go back to
her bedroom. Staff 2 was checking her phone. Youth B walked
down the call. Staff 3 and Staff 2 walked back and attempted to
secure Youth A’s arms. Youth B and Youth D came back down
the hall and Staff 2 let go of Youth A and stood up and directed
Youth B and Youth D to go back to their bedrooms. Youth B and
Youth D remained in the hall, Staff 2 held Youth A’s arm and let
go again. Staff 2 and Staff 3 continued to tell Youth A to let Staff 1
go. Youth B and Youth D walked into the living room. Staff 2 went
down to the living room and Staff 3 yelled for Staff 2 to come back.
Staff 2 came back and secured Youth A’s arm. Youth D came
back and bent down in front of Youth A and talked to Youth A.
Youth D told Youth A Staff 1 had had enough and there was blood
and to let go of her. Staff 2 and Staff 3 remained holding Youth
A’s arms which appeared to be a loose hold and told Youth A to
let go. Staff 2 received a phone call and answered the phone.
Staff 2 and Staff 3 let go of Youth A. Youth A stood up and went
out the door.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as Youth A was assaulting Staff
1 and no improper techniques were used. Staff 2 and Staff 3
attempted to restrain Youth A, however they were unsuccessful
based on the size differential of Youth A compared to Staff 2 and
Staff 3. Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 attempted to use the proper
restraint techniques however were unsuccessful as well as Youth
A was attempting to assault Staff 2 and Staff 3 when they
attempted to intervene when Youth A was assaulting Staff 1.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
• The facility address professionalism with staff as Staff 1,
Staff 2, and Staff 3 were smiling and laughing outside
Youth A’s bedroom door when attempting to open the door.
• The facility ensure staff are scheduled to ensure staff are
able to preform the trained interventions if necessary.
• The facility use this situation as a way to train staff in the
future.
• The facility train staff to remain in the area of the incident
and make phone calls if needed in the area of the situation
18

to provide additional support if needed. In this situation
Supervisor had pulled up the camera footage and directed
staff to call law enforcement, however in the future, if video
footage is pulled by on-call staff and recognize law
enforcement is needed, on-call make appropriate calls to
allow staff in the home to address the situation until law
enforcement arrives.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
Description (1) A child caring institution, including private secure juvenile
justice facilities, shall establish a process improvement and
restraint reduction/elimination plan that:
(d) Staff must complete refresher training annually or more
frequently as needed.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff were not trained in verbal de-escalation annually.
Investigation Interviews:
Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on 5/5/2025. Chief Administrator reported she did not
know if staff were receiving annual verbal de-escalation training.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on 4/28/2025. Staff 1
reported she did not recall if she received additional verbal de-
escalation training at the facility after she completed preservice
training.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/5/2025.
Staff 2 reported she received verbal de-escalation training when
she started at the facility and attended preservice training,
however, has not received any verbal de-escalation training since.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 5/12/2025. Staff 3
reported she received verbal de-escalation training when she first
started at the facility and received additional trainings including
BBI training in December 2024.
Documents Reviewed:
• Teaching Family Homes Physical Restraint Policy: All staff
within our agency who work directly with youth will be trained
in approved crisis prevention and intervention techniques,
this includes but is not limited to: Prevention, de-escalation
techniques, and non-violent responses to assaultive
19

behaviors, conflict management, minimizing trauma for
youth, and staff emotional self-regulation techniques.
Training will be conducted by certified trainers. Staff are
trained on these techniques prior to being scheduled on
shifts with the youth. Staff must complete refresher training
on an annual (at minimum) basis. Our agency will maintain
training logs and other training documentation to verify staff
are trained.
• Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3’s personnel files: Staff 1
received Effective Praise training and Crisis Teaching on
11/16/2023 and Corrective Teaching training on
11/17/2023. Staff 2 received Effective Praise training on
6/21/2023, Corrective Teaching training on 6/22/2023, and
Crisis Teaching on 6/22/2023. Staff 3 received Effective
Praise training on 11/16/2023, Corrective Teaching training
and Crisis Teaching on 11/17/2023. Staff 1, Staff 2, and
Staff 3’s training records did not indicate any annual verbal
de-escalation training.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff
3 did not receive annual verbal de-escalation training.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
• The facility address laughing and smiling in escalated
situations to be unacceptable as this behavior escalates
situations further.
• The facility labels annual verbal de-escalation training
clearly in staff training records and ensures verbal de-
scalation training occurs annually.
Conclusion Violation Established
20

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
